metadata.titleEn: 10 m meteorological gradient data set of hulugou basin (2012)
metadata.description:
1. Data overview:
This data set is the scale meteorological gradient data of qilian station from January 1, 2012 to December 31, 2012 (installed at the end of September 2011).VG1000 gradient observation system carries out long-term monitoring of wind speed, wind direction, air temperature, humidity, radiation and other conventional meteorological elements, and carries out data storage and processing analysis in combination with the data collector with high precision and high scanning frequency.
2. Data content:
The main observation factors include four layers of air temperature, humidity and two-dimensional ultrasonic wind, rain and snow volume meter, eight layers of ground temperature, soil moisture content, etc.
3. Space and time range:
Geographical coordinates: longitude: longitude: 99° 52’e;Latitude: 38°15 'N;Height: 3232.3 m
metadata.instructions: Data file name: hulugou watershed 2012 10m meteorological gradient data set.xlsx; WPS or excel and other software can be used for viewing and editing.

background: Understanding cryospheric hydrology and the effects of cryospheric changes on river runoff is critical for sustainable water management especially in arid inland river basins such as those in northwest China where water resources mainly come from alpine areas. The Earth’s cryosphere is facing rapid changes in the duration, extent, and mass of snow and ice, which have had multiple impacts on the environment across a range of temporal and spatial scales. Changes in mountain snow, glaciers, and permafrost have resulted in significant downstream impacts in terms of the quantity, seasonality, and quality of water. This shrinkage has modified the water cycle and river discharge in cold regions and caused the rise of global mean sea level. Serving as a solid reservoir for many endorheic and exorheic basins, the mountain cryosphere is the regulator of major rivers and provides most of the water resources in arid regions in China and its neighboring countries. However, because of inadequate observation data and the lack of knowledge about many aspects of cryospheric hydrometeorology at regional scales in alpine regions, the significance of the impacts of cryospheric changes and the severity of their consequences remain unclear in China.
research objective: The scientific objective of the CHOICE is to obtain comprehensive observation data about environmental factors to determine the hydrological processes in a mountainous region and to evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in the lower arid regions. Four key science questions have been identified: The spatial and temporal distribution of alpine precipitation need to be determined. The effects of cryospheric changes on streamflow need to be determined. The effects of changes in the vegetation pattern in the vertical landscape zones on water balance and river runoff in the mountains must be assessed. A suitable distributed hydrological model including cryospheric hydrology is needed in mountainous areas.
challenges: Understanding such changes in these vulnerable regions has posed significant challenges because of their remoteness and sparse observations. Precipitation observations are still beset with significant biases and errors.
methods: Each AWS features the long-term monitoring of the following meteorological variables: air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature (LST), soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount. We also conducted long-term standard meteorological field (SMF) manual observations for reference to those obtained at AWS. The total discharge has been monitored by a continuously stream-gauging station at the catchment outlet since 2009. From 2009 to 2012, we also manually used the float protocol and a stopwatch to estimate the nonfreezing period discharge in a meadow subcatchment and a moraine–talus subcatchment. To apply hydrological models in the alpine catchment, we have obtained long-term continuous soil parameter data in the soil pit synchronously with those collected at AWS. An SI-111 infrared radiometer (Apogee Instr. Inc.) was used to measure the LST. During the early stage of the CHOICE, evapotranspiration was measured with two manual weighing microlysimeters, which were 40 cm in depth and 31.5 cm in diameter and were installed in the SMF at the Hulu-1 field on 1 July 2009 with an electronic scale of 2 g (0.026 mm) in precision. With the development of the CHOICE, five automatic microlysimeters (CHOICE-LYS40, T&D) were arranged in the same field as the AWS of the Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 field in August 2013. An EC150 system (Campbell Scientific Inc.) was installed on a lattice mast at 5.8 m at the Hulu-2 field in September 2011. Four cluster wells were installed in 2011 and 2014 for groundwater monitoring and sampling. On fixed-point scale, six SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors (Campbell Scientific Inc.) measure snow depth synchronously with AWS. In this system, three thermistor cables were installed that crossed the riverbed–water, water–ice, and ice–air interfaces. We conduct the work of precipitation intercomparisons by referring to the Solid Precipitation Intercomparison Experiment of the WMO using pit gauges and a double reference intercomparison reference (DFIR) gauge. Precipitation measurements in the Hulu catchment were performed with six total rain-weighing sensors (TRwS204, MPS System Ltd) with a single alter shield and synchronized with AWS. Fourteen LST observation sites with similar elevations but different aspects and slopes were built around the Hulu-3 field. Two LST observation sites were built to analyze the influences of plants on LST. To study the runoff process of canopy precipitation to surface runoff in different landscapes, two runoff fields (shrubs and meadows) (15 by 3 m) were established at a shrub-encroached alpine meadow hillslope in September 2010. Four methods were used to measure soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity in the Hulu-1 field including a single-ring infiltrometer, a double-ring infiltrometer, a Hood infiltrometer (Hood IL-2700, Germany), and the ring cutter method. Groundwater samples used for isotope analysis were collected from 12 wells between 2014 and 2016, and stream water samples were collected from 12 sites that were approximately evenly distributed from upstream to downstream between 2011 and 2016. A Picarro GasScouter G4301 gas concentration analyzer with a re-entry control system and six respiration chambers installed on the permafrost zone of the Hulu catchment in August 2017. The observation period of canopy precipitation interception began in June 2010. A total of four sap flow sensors (CAF, ECOMATIK) were installed to estimate transpiration. Variations in the diversity of the soil microbial community under meadow, shrub, marshy meadow, and moraine–talus were observed along an elevation gradient in the Hulu catchment in July 2013. An AWS was erected at the top of the glacier (4817 m asl) in September 2015; the site is not affected by the surrounding mountains. To obtain reliable turbulent data, EC system measurements were made adjacent to the AWS at a height of 4 m beginning in October 2017. To harvest the water contained in fog, five identical standard fog collectors were installed at Hulu-1 to Hulu-5 in July 2014. A warming simulation experiment was begun in September 2016. Two flight campaigns were performed in the Hulu catchment.
findings: In recent years, a series of studies have been published using the CHOICE sharing platform data, and a number of researchers have used the CHOICE data for studies of alpine meteorology, cryospheric hydrology, groundwater, soils, and isotopes. According to the six AWS of the CHOICE obtained throughout the Hulu catchment and peripheral precipitation data from five China Meteorological Administration stations (Zhangye, Minle, Sunan, Qilian, and Yeniugou), two or more yearly EMPs exist in the northern Qilian Mountains. A diminished accumulation zone will result in a reduction in the transport and expansion of the glaciers, and then the glaciers will have to retreat to limit themselves to reduce ablation. Based on 10-yr observations in the western cold regions of China, especially those obtained in the Upper Hei River basin (UHR), a new CBHM was created to evaluate the effects of cryospheric changes on stream flow from the UHR. In the past 50 yr, river runoff has generally shown an increasing trend as a result of increased rainfall, snowfall, and glacial runoff in the cold regions of western China.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for measuring snow depth in mountainous cryospheric regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used for measuring snow depth involves using six SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors (Campbell Scientific Inc.) that measure snow depth synchronously with Automatic Weather Stations (AWS) in the Hulu catchment.

Example.Question: What is an example of a technique employed to monitor evapotranspiration in a cryospheric hydrological study?
Example.Answer: An example of a technique for monitoring evapotranspiration includes the use of two manual weighing microlysimeters, which were 40 cm in depth and 31.5 cm in diameter, installed with an electronic scale of 2 g (0.026 mm) precision. Additionally, five automatic microlysimeters (CHOICE-LYS40, T&D) were arranged in the same field as the AWS for precise measurements.

Example.Question: Can you describe an example of how soil water infiltration is measured in cryospheric hydrology research?
Example.Answer: An example of measuring soil water infiltration involves using four methods, including a single-ring infiltrometer, a double-ring infiltrometer, a Hood infiltrometer (Hood IL-2700, Germany), and the ring cutter method. These methods were utilized in the Hulu-1 field to assess soil water infiltration and hydraulic conductivity.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using an automatic weather station (AWS) in cryospheric hydrology studies?
Definition.Answer: In cryospheric hydrology studies, an automatic weather station (AWS) is significant for the long-term monitoring of meteorological variables such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, and radiation components. This data is crucial for understanding hydrological processes and the impacts of climate change on water resources in mountainous regions.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with collecting cryospheric hydrology data in remote mountainous areas, and how are these challenges addressed?
Definition.Answer: Challenges associated with collecting cryospheric hydrology data in remote mountainous areas include remoteness, sparse observations, and significant biases in precipitation data. These challenges are addressed by using advanced technology like AWS, infrared radiometers, and a combination of manual and automated measurements to ensure comprehensive data collection and reliability.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in challenges faced when collecting data in remote alpine regions compared to data collection in urban environments?
Comparison.Answer: Challenges in remote alpine regions include their remoteness and sparse observations, which lead to significant biases and errors in precipitation data. In contrast, urban environments might face challenges related to data interference from human activities and infrastructure. Both environments require tailored approaches to ensure data accuracy and reliability, but the specific challenges and solutions differ due to their unique conditions.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the challenges in data collection for cryospheric hydrometeorology in alpine regions based on the observed biases and errors in precipitation data?
Interpretation.Answer: Understanding changes in vulnerable alpine regions is challenging due to their remoteness and sparse observation networks, leading to significant biases and errors, especially in precipitation data.

Interpretation.Question: How do the various meteorological variables monitored by AWS improve our understanding of hydrological processes in mountainous regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The long-term monitoring of meteorological variables such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, and soil moisture by AWS allows for a comprehensive understanding of hydrological processes, crucial for evaluating climate, cryosphere, and land cover impacts on mountainous hydrology.

Interpretation.Question: What does the integration of manual and automatic methods for measuring meteorological variables indicate about the reliability and accuracy of data collection techniques in this domain?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration suggests a strategy to enhance the reliability and accuracy of data collection, combining the detailed observations from manual methods with the continuous data from automatic systems to mitigate potential errors and biases.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the significant biases and errors in precipitation observations in remote and sparsely observed regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Precipitation observations in remote and sparsely observed regions are beset with significant biases and errors due to the challenges of accessing these areas, the limitations of observation equipment, and the variability of precipitation patterns that are difficult to capture accurately with sparse data points.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the implications for hydrological model development if long-term continuous soil parameter data are not integrated with AWS data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: If long-term continuous soil parameter data are not integrated with AWS data, it could lead to less accurate hydrological models that fail to capture the complexity of soil-vegetation-atmosphere interactions. This omission could result in models that do not accurately reflect the influence of soil moisture and temperature dynamics on evapotranspiration and groundwater recharge, potentially leading to inaccurate predictions of streamflow and water availability in mountainous regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of collecting long-term meteorological and hydrological data using various instruments in alpine regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to obtain comprehensive observation data about environmental factors to determine the hydrological processes in a mountainous region and to evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in the lower arid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to ensure the accuracy and reliability of meteorological data collected in remote alpine environments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Meteorological data in remote alpine environments are collected using long-term monitoring at Automatic Weather Stations (AWS) for variables such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, and soil moisture. Manual observations at Standard Meteorological Fields (SMF) are conducted to reference the AWS data. Precipitation measurements are synchronized with AWS and employ various sensors and gauges to mitigate biases and errors.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are cryospheric changes and their effects on hydrology assessed using the data collection techniques available?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Cryospheric changes are assessed using comprehensive observation data that includes the monitoring of snow depth, streamflow, and soil parameters. Instruments like Sonic Ranging Sensors for snow depth and stream-gauging stations for discharge measurement are used. Long-term soil data collection and standard meteorological observations help evaluate the hydrological processes and the effects of cryosphere changes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps for integrating various data collection methods to develop a distributed hydrological model in a mountainous region?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Developing a distributed hydrological model involves integrating diverse data collection methods such as long-term meteorological observations, soil parameter monitoring, and streamflow measurements. This includes using AWS for continuous data, manual observations for validation, and employing hydrological modeling techniques to simulate the effects of climate, vegetation, and cryospheric changes on water resources.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the integration of cryospheric changes into hydrological models for improved water resource management in alpine regions?
Enablement.Answer: A suitable distributed hydrological model including cryospheric hydrology is needed in mountainous areas to assess the impacts of cryospheric changes on streamflow and water resources in arid regions.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in automated weather stations facilitate the long-term monitoring of meteorological variables in remote alpine catchments?
Enablement.Answer: Each AWS features the long-term monitoring of variables like air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, land surface temperature, soil temperature, soil moisture, snow depth, and precipitation amount, enabling comprehensive data collection in remote areas.

Expectation.Question: Why is it challenging to obtain accurate precipitation observations in mountainous cryospheric regions?
Expectation.Answer: Understanding changes in vulnerable regions like mountainous cryospheric areas poses significant challenges due to their remoteness and sparse observations. Precipitation observations are still beset with significant biases and errors.

Expectation.Question: Why might integrating cryospheric hydrology into hydrological models be crucial for understanding water resources in alpine regions?
Expectation.Answer: A suitable distributed hydrological model including cryospheric hydrology is needed in mountainous areas to evaluate the effects of climate, cryosphere, and land cover changes on mountainous hydrology and water resources in lower arid regions. This integration is crucial to assess the impacts of cryospheric changes on streamflow and water balance.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in collecting meteorological data in alpine regions, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: Understanding changes in alpine regions poses significant challenges due to their remoteness and sparse observations. Precipitation observations are particularly prone to biases and errors. Addressing these challenges may involve enhancing the spatial distribution of observational networks, using advanced technologies like AWS and EC systems, and integrating manual observations with automated systems for comprehensive data collection.

Judgmental.Question: How might the current methods of monitoring soil moisture and temperature in alpine regions be improved to enhance data accuracy and reliability?
Judgmental.Answer: Current methods involve using AWS for continuous monitoring and soil parameter data collection in soil pits. To improve data accuracy and reliability, employing more advanced sensors with higher precision and incorporating remote sensing technologies could provide more comprehensive spatial coverage and finer temporal resolution of soil moisture and temperature data.

Judgmental.Question: What evaluation can be made regarding the effectiveness of using multiple observation sites with different elevations and aspects for LST data collection in mountainous regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of multiple observation sites with varying elevations and aspects is effective in capturing the diverse microclimates within mountainous terrains. This approach allows for a more detailed understanding of how factors like elevation and aspect influence LST, which is essential for accurately modeling and predicting climatic and environmental changes in these regions.

Assertion.Question: I can’t make sense of why measuring precipitation in these mountainous areas is so challenging.
Assertion.Answer: The challenges in measuring precipitation in mountainous areas stem from significant biases and errors due to the remote location and sparse observations. Precipitation measurements are enhanced using various instruments like pit gauges, DFIR gauges, and rain-weighing sensors synchronized with AWS to improve accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and summarize the various data collection methods utilized in monitoring meteorological variables in mountainous regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods include the use of AWS for long-term monitoring of meteorological variables such as air temperature, humidity, wind speed, and radiation. Manual observations were conducted for reference to AWS data. Specialized equipment like the SI-111 infrared radiometer and EC150 system were used for specific measurements like land surface temperature and evapotranspiration. Groundwater and snow depth monitoring were achieved through cluster wells and SR50A Sonic Ranging Sensors, respectively.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and describe the challenges faced in collecting precipitation data in remote alpine regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting precipitation data include significant biases and errors in observations due to the remoteness and sparse distribution of monitoring stations. Precipitation intercomparisons were conducted using pit gauges and DFIR gauges. Additionally, precipitation was measured with rain-weighing sensors synchronized with AWS, highlighting difficulties in achieving accurate and representative data collection.
